Janice A. Radway, Reading the Romance: Women, Patriarchy, and Popular Literature (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1984), describes a readership markedly less educated, less affluent, and less urban than the editors of the books they read. She also notes that the readers detect contempt for them in the publishers' attitudes and behavior (114-16).
Wendy Simonds, Women and Self-Help Culture: Reading Between the Lines (New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press, 1992)

Rubin, The Making of Middlebrow Culture, chap. 3: "Although Scherman, Canby, and Fisher all made repeated statements about the danger of underestimating the intelligence of the American people, and although Scherman kept admonishing the board members to pick the books that they, as representatives of average readers, thought best, in practice the judges knew very well that they had an audience to serve whose education and taste did not match their own" (145)
Janice A. Radway, A Feeling for Books: The Book-of-the-Month Club, Literary Taste, and Middle-Class Desire (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1997), esp. Part I

[Ibid.] Radway notes that "Joe [Savago]'s tendency to draw a distinction between his personal taste for high literary fiction and the more tolerant taste he exercised institutionally on behalf of the club recurred consistently in my interviews with the other editors" (61)

[Beth Luey], "Who Reads Nonfiction?" Publishing Research Quarterly 14 (Spring 1998): 21-35
